Treatment for Kit No. 1
page seven
NARR: Now a map has been known to mislead. And an artist's drawing can
distort. But • . • man told himself naively . • and with pardonable
error . . in a photograph nothing stood between you and the absolute
reality. Reality at home. Or reality from abroad, brought to him in
magazines and newspapers by photoengraving.
Well, things didn't stand still for long. With his attention momentarily
distracted from reading, man became aware of a disconserting log . .
Narrator and camera are moving toward next display ... the sound unit,
NARR: In extending his eyes, he had forgotten his earsi Stupid really . , •
because now he could SEE much, much farther than he could HEAR.
Moreover, he could see people, places and events at his convenience . .
after days, weeks, even years had elapsed. But he could hear only
those sounds being made HERE . . and NOW. How frustrating ...
when the widening world was alive with exciting and instructive sound!
So he took steps to close that gap. His inventive brain applied
itself further to this business of communications . • • and In the last
three decades of the nineteenth centory, it hit pay dirt three times!
Now man had:
Conversation across distance with the face-to-face feeling and
the immediacy of personal presence . • in this:
(THE TELEPHONE)
